case_vignette: On day-of-life 2, a 3-day-old boy who was born with no visible skin problems begins to develop erosions and bullae over both the palmar and plantar surfaces. These bullae are localized to areas of friction or trauma (eg, where electrocardiogram leads were placed). The mother’s pregnancy was normal, and the infant had been born without complications. Aside from the development of bullae, the infant has no evidence of any other medical problems. The infant’s parents are healthy and have no medical problems. No one in the infant’s family has had similar dermatologic findings.
question: What is the final diagnosis?

No, I was born without any visible skin problems.

No, I have not been exposed to any harsh chemicals or substances.
Have you been in contact with anyone who has had a skin condition similar to yours?
No one in my family has had similar skin problems.

I am only 3 days old, so I haven't been in contact with travelers or been to tropical regions.

No, I haven't been in contact with any animals or pets.

No, I haven't been in contact with any plants or trees.

No, I haven't been in contact with any dust or debris.

No, I haven't been in contact with any unusual water sources.

I've had some contact where medical equipment, like electrocardiogram leads, was placed on my skin.
Have you been in contact with any medical equipment recently?
Yes, I've had contact with medical equipment like electrocardiogram leads.
Final Diagnosis: Contact Dermatitis.
